title: labour party working class vote theresa may conservative party
story: Theresa May could win the votes of a disenfranchised New Working Class that previously backed LabourPolicy expert Claire Ainsley, executive of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, argues a new social class that makes up a large percentage of the vote is now up for grabs &ndash and that Theresa May could welcome them with open arms.Ms Ainsley warns mainstream politicians have focused too much on middle classes and swing voters and stressed not enough time and focus has been spent on looking at the changing nature of Britain's workforce.She said: There is a working class, it&rsquos new, and no political party is speaking for it.&ldquoThere are millions of people today on low and middle incomes, and politicians need to wake up and start paying attention to them.                Nanny-state ROASTED as just elite 'controlling lower classes'                 Shameless Corbyn has betrayed the working classes says STEPHEN POLLARD&ldquoThere&rsquos a prize on offer for the parties who understand this.She also predicted that people on low and middle incomes are less likely to associate with Labour now than they used to.She continued: &ldquoWorking class support for Labour has declined, it&rsquos started to rise a bit for the Tories, and has definitely increased among the SNP.Radical changes to the economy and society means the world of work is largely different to what it was 40 years ago, and that disenfranchised Labour voters have floated away.By 2005, working class support for Labour had tailed off, and they had begun to not vote for anyone at all, according to the Joseph Rowntree Foundation executive.Ms Ainsley said the message for politicians was simple - tell voters what you are going to do, and then show them when you&rsquove done it.She suggests new policies such as an extra bank holiday, a crackdown on soaring shop prices and a massive housebuilding programme could capture working class voters.In her new book, The New Working Class: how to win hearts, minds and votes, Ms Ainsley says: &ldquoNew Labour was right to suppose that Labour could now build a parliamentary majority based on the traditional working class alone, but they were wrong to assume those voters would have nowhere else to go.Outspoken Shadow Home Secretary, Diane Abbott holds strong opinions which does not always go down well.                     Getty Images1 of 11Abortion is an issue of conscience for the Labour party.She details how many of the so-called New Working Class' earns less than the average annual income of &pound27,000 and also has difficulty taking their first steps onto the property ladder.Ms Ainsley said the new class are likely to be female and younger than previous voters &ndash but said that political parties needed to appeal to their values of family, fairness, hard work and decency.In her book Ms Ainsley also proposes radical new policies, such as an extra bank holiday, a clampdown on excessive price rises for basic goods and services and a points-based immigration system so that the public are happy with the number of workers that enter the country.She also detailed the idea of a national house building programme, banning MPs from having second jobs and banning all job perks altogether and ensuring self-employed staff and contract workers are entitled to receiving sick pay and benefits.

title: prince harry prince charles speech meghan markle buckingham palace garden party
story: PAPrince Harry delivered a heartwarming speechAs the Duke of Sussex praised his father, who he affectionately calls Pa, during a tender speech at Buckingham Palace, his new wife was seen smiling and laughing.The Buckingham Palace Garden Party on Tuesday saw the couple delay their honeymoon to celebrate Prince Charles&rsquo 70th birthday - six months early.Prince Harry told guests how his father had &ldquoinspired him and Prince William as children as the Duchess of Cornwall and Charles looked on.The Duke of Sussex&rsquos speech in full below.Good afternoon and welcome to Buckingham Palace.&ldquoWe are here today to reflect on, and to celebrate, my father&rsquos dedicated support to all of you and the work that you do.                Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, wears green for Prince Charles' birthday                Prince Harry praises &lsquoselfless&rsquo Charles at 70th Birthday Celebration&ldquoBut first, I would like us to take a moment to remember all those affected by the tragic events at the Manchester Arena a year ago. We are fortunate to have over 250 representatives from the Emergency Services here today.It is right that we take a moment to recognise the amazing work they do every day and how each member of our Blue Light Services rise to meet the challenge of tragic events such as the attack a year ago.We are also joined by Youth United Cadets. Their organisation also provided triage support to the medical crews on the attack.&ldquoSo, on behalf of my family and everyone here, I would like to say thank you to the Emergency Services and all those who supported the injured and affected.My brother, William, would be here today, were he not attending the service in Manchester to honour the victims, their families, the Emergency Services and the survivors, this afternoon.Our thoughts are with those who lost loved ones and those still dealing with the experiences of that night.PAMeghan could not stop smiling &ldquoIt really is amazing to see so many of you here today for this family celebration.I say &lsquofamily&rsquo because this is a chance for us to honour The Prince of Wales's work over the last forty plus years, with all of his charities, patronages and military associations &ndash and, as you all know, my father views all of your organisations like an extended family.&ldquoAs I was preparing for this afternoon, I looked through the long list of those who had been invited.Pa, I was again struck by the range and ersity of the work which you are involved with.Currently there are your two major charities, The Prince's Trust and the newly formed &ndash Prince's Foundation &ndash which has brought together your work supporting vulnerable young people in society, the built environment, culture, heritage and education.These sit alongside your 18 military associations and more than 420 patronages, ranging from music and the arts to rare breeds and plant life.Although the subjects vary enormously, I know that the way in which you work with each of them does not.&ldquoWho amongst you has not known the joy, and perhaps trepidation at receiving a handwritten note in response to some news shared from your organisation, urging you on and asking for more to be done to address this issue or that?Who has not come away from a meeting with my father, their head spinning with a dozen new ideas which he wants to get underway urgently, having met a group of people or read something that has fired his imagination and started the flow of ideas.&ldquoHis enthusiasm and energy are truly infectious it has certainly inspired William and I to get involved in issues we care passionately about and to do whatever we can to make a difference.In fact, many of the issues William and I now work on are subjects we were introduced to by our father growing up.His passion and dedication are remarkable and seeing so many of you here today, I cannot fail but to be in awe of the drive he has had for so many years, to contribute to the enrichment of society both in this country and around the world.PAThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex at Prince Charles birthday celebrationPAPrince Charles, Duchess of Cornwall Camilla and Duchess of Sussex, Meghan at the celebrations&ldquoBut Pa, in my mind, this event sums up your approach to work &ndash I know you really didn&rsquot want today to be about you and would far rather the focus be on the people and organisations represented here.I know that in your mind, you see the opportunity of bringing everyone together as a chance to thank them for all of their amazing work!It is your selfless drive to affect change, whether that is to improve the lives of those who are on the wrong path, to save an important piece of our national heritage or to protect a particular species under threat, which William and I draw inspiration from every day.&ldquoSo, Pa, while I know that you've asked that today not be about you, you must forgive me if I don&rsquot listen to you &ndash much like when I was younger &ndash and instead, I ask everyone here to say a huge thank you to you, for your incredible work over nearly 50 years.Work that has given self-confidence and opportunity to thousands of young people who might not have had the best start in lifeOr to champion causes like climate change long before almost anyone else was talking about it and above all, for your vision and ability to bring people together to make change happen.&ldquoYou have inspired William and I, and looking out here today, it is clear to see that we are not alone. You have created an incredible body of work that has, and will continue to make such a huge difference to so many people's lives both here and around the world.&ldquoWith that, Ladies and Gentlemen, please can I ask you to join me in wishing The Prince of Wales a very Happy Birthday &ndash 6 months ahead of his 70th! How very Royal!

title: kate middleton princess charlotte prince george pictures childrens hospice week
story: The Duchess of Cambridge said it is the small family moments that make each day specialForget the clothing allowance making her the envy of women around the world or the multiple royal residences: in a message today she describes the small moments in family life that make each day special.Kate, 35, wrote the personal message in support of hospices and palliative care charities helping children with life-limiting illnesses.It is Children&rsquos Hospice Week, organised by Together for Short Lives, an umbrella charity for children&rsquos palliative care, and the theme is Life&rsquos Short so make the most of those small moments.In the letter, the Duchess, who has met many dying children in her role as patron of East Anglia&rsquos Children&rsquos Hospices (EACH) since 2012, said: &ldquo I am touched that children and young people are sharing what they love most in life and reminding us of how precious time is for everyone.                Royal Wedding reception: What did the Duchess of Cambridge wear to ...                Kate Middleton wears giant citrine stone ring to Royal Wedding &ndash gift                     Getty1 of 19Princess Diana and Kate Middleton pose with their young familiesDuchess of CambridgeBy supporting Children&rsquos Hospice Week we can help them spread joy and positivity across the UK, encouraging everyone to make the most of moments that matter&ldquoSpending quality time together is such an important aspect of family life and for me, as a mother, it is the simple family moments like playing outside together that I cherish.Graham Butland, EACH Chief Executive, said: &ldquoWe&rsquore privileged to have the continued support of Her Royal Highness, who has done so much to raise awareness of not only EACH, but children&rsquos hospices right across the country.&ldquoThis most recent show of support emphasises what an important role we play when time is short, helping families make the most of their precious time together and create memories that last forever.

title: Meghan Markle Prince Harry Australia tour commonwealth invictus games Western Australia
story: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry are set to visit Australia in October for the Invictus GamesMeghan and Harry&rsquos visit to Australia will be part of a multiple destination tour, likely to include Tonga, Fiji and New Zealand, to underline the couple&rsquos strong commitment to the Commonwealth.But regional governments including Western Australia are already lobbying Kensington Palace to secure a visit from the in-demand couple.Mark McGowan, the Premier of Western Australia, commented on a potential visit, stating: &ldquoWestern Australia is the western gateway to Australia and is the ideal spot for the royal couple to start or finish their Australian adventure.&ldquoWe have so many unique experiences to offer and it would be a great honour if the Duke and Duchess of Sussex could spend some time getting to explore our extraordinary State.                Prince Harry&rsquos heartwarming speech to &lsquoPa&rsquo Prince Charles IN FULL                Princess Diana was 'hands on' and Meghan will follow in her footstepsMs Markle carried out her first royal engagement since her wedding today at Buckingham PalacePrince Charles visited Gove in Australia's Northern Territory in AprilPrince Harry last visited Western Australia in 2015 for a four week secondment to the Australian Defence Force.He was stationed in army barracks in Bindoon near Perth, as well as in Darwin and Sydney, and carried out training exercises and domestic deployments during his stay.The couple are also being lobbied by the government of New South Wales, who are seeking to secure a visit following their stop-off in Sydney for the Invictus Games.They will reportedly stay in Bathurst, a former gold and coal mining town located 200km west of Sydney.The town is located in the Blue Mountains, and is the site of the renowned Bathurst 100 touring care race, which attracts thousands of spectators each year.The royal duo are even delaying their honeymoon plans to make way for their packed schedule of royal engagements and tours in the coming months.Prince Harry signalled his strong commitment to the Commonwealth after being appointed Commonwealth Youth Ambassador shortly before the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in London in April.Commenting on his appointment, he said: &ldquoIn my new role, I will work to support The Queen, my father The Prince of Wales, and my brother William, all of whom know that young people are the answer to the challenges of today.&ldquoI am also incredibly grateful that the woman I am about to marry, Meghan, will be joining me in this work, of which she too is hugely excited to take part in.Meghan Markle, Duchess of Sussex and Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex are in attendance at the Prince of Wales' 70th Birthday Patronage Celebration at Buckingham Palace Gardens.                    PA1 of 13The Duchess of Sussex at a garden party at Buckingham PalaceAnd speaking about the Commonwealth&rsquos young iniduals in particular, he added: &ldquoThe young adults I have met across the Commonwealth have shown me time and again that your generation understands something very important: that to tackle a big challenge, you need to focus on the root causes, not the symptoms.&ldquoAs I travel around the Commonwealth in my work on behalf of The Royal Family, it is striking to see just how different today's generation of young adults are.&ldquoYou are connected. You have made positive use of technology to build relationships within your communities, nations and across the globe.&ldquoYou care. You want your nations to be cleaner, your planet to be greener, your friends and neighbours to be treated fairly and with respect, no matter their ethnicity, their religion, or their status.&ldquoYou are optimistic. The complicated challenges we face &ndash climate change, inequality, conflict &ndash they do not discourage you. Rather, they inspire you to persevere and effect change.

title: Space news science supernova Earth extinction discovery
story: The supernova is thought to have occurred between 163 and 326 light-years away The supernova is thought to have occurred between 163 and 326 light-years away (50&ndash100 parsecs) from Earth.Harmful ionising radiation can sterilise nearby inhabited planets and one researcher wanted to discover if it was the cause for mass extinction on Earth based on geologic evidence of nearby supernovae.Astrophysicist at Washburn University in Kansas Brian Thomas investigated cosmic rays from the supernovae as they propagated through the atmosphere to the surface to understand their effect on living organisms.Speaking to Astrobiology Magazine, Mr Thomas said: &ldquoThere were changes, especially in Africa, which went from being more forested to more grassland.                WW3 WARNING: Britain must prepare for attacks in space, warns RAFWe are interested in how exploding stars affect life on Earth, and it turns out a few million years ago there were changes in the things that were living at the time.It might have been connected to this supernova.During the time period, geologic records show an elevated global concentration of Iron-60 which is a radioactive isotope produced during a supernova.There was a change in the abundance of species during the Pliocene-Pleistocene period.No major mass extinctions happened but there was a higher rate of extinction in general.There was a change in the abundance of species during the Pliocene-Pleistocene periodMr Thomas added Earth&rsquos ozone layer protects all biology from harmful, genetically altering ultraviolet (UV) radiation.He used global climate models, recent atmospheric chemistry models and radiative transfer (the propagation of radiation through the layers of the atmosphere) to investigate and better understand how the flux of cosmic rays from supernovae would alter Earth&rsquos ozone layer.Mr Thomas told Astrobiology Magazine supernovae does not blast everything at once.Instead the intergalactic medium acts as a kind of sieve, slows down the arrival of cosmic rays and radioactive iron rain over hundreds of thousands of years.A decrease in ozone could be a concern for life on the surface.Mr Thomas told Astrobiology Magazine supernovae does not blast everything at onceWhen asked if nearby supernovae will result in mass extinctions, Mr Thomas said it depends.He added: There is a subtler shift instead of a 'wipe-out everything,' some organisms are better off and some are worse off.For example plants showed increase yield, like soybean and wheat, while others showed reduced productivity.Referring to the changes in species in the fossil record, Mr Thomas said &ldquoit fits.Computational physicist at the Blue Marble Space Institute of Science in Seattle Dimitra Atri said: This work is an important step towards understanding the impact of nearby supernovae on our biosphere.

title: Brexit news MP Ian Paisley jr blasts Remainers Irish border Issue EU Theresa May
story: The DUP MP for North Antrim bullishly defended Theresa May&rsquos Brexit plan, insisting that Britain will fully leave the EU.Mr Paisley made his comments in a Channel 4 News interview about the his party's stance on Brexit and the Irish border issue.When host Krishnan Guru Murthy suggested that the DUP would back a customs arrangement with a transitional arrangement keeping the UK in the single market into the &ldquodistant future, the DUP MP was blunt in his response.He said: &ldquoThat sounds like the biggest cloud of mush that I&rsquove ever actually heard.&ldquoThat&rsquos not what we are doing.&ldquoWe are leaving the EU. We know that we leave next March and we know that after that there&rsquos a short transition period to resolve some issues that of course have to be resolved, and fishing of course has been one of the issues that has been identified, in terms of setting what catch limits will be.Channel 4 NewsThe DUP MP slammed Remainers for playing politics with the Irish border issue&ldquoThe idea that you can be half pregnant, half in, half out, isn&rsquot on.&ldquoThis is a revolutionary change, and we are leaving the EU.&ldquoPeople have got to get used to that.Mr Paisley insisted: &ldquoTrying to play off the Northern Ireland issue for purely sectarian and isive reasons, as has happened in Northern Ireland with some parties and has happened with the Republic of Ireland trying to do that, is completely and totally wrong, and in fact futile.&ldquoThere&rsquos a lot of people who see clearly through that.The issue of a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland after Britain leaves the EU remains a bitterly isive one that is yet to be resolved.Brussels insists that that the only way to avoid physical infrastructure for customs checks between the UK and EU on the border is to maintain regulatory alignment between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.The EU&rsquos plans would effectively keep Northern Ireland in the customs union, a proposal that has been rejected by Theresa May and DUP leader Arlene Foster, leaving negotiations in limbo.On Monday, Conservative MP Owen Paterson and DUP MP Sammy Wilson penned a joint letter in the  in which they blasted the way in which Remainers had &ldquorecklessly exploited the Irish border issue.They wrote: Brussels and Dublin&rsquos disregard for the Good Friday Agreement is troubling.&ldquoWhen Michel Barnier proposed ignoring it by simply annexing Northern Ireland to the customs union, Theresa May rightly rejected this outrageous suggestion.&ldquoWhat concerns us is that some Irish politicians claim things of the Agreement that plainly aren&rsquot in it, while routinely ignoring what is.

title: tesco direct close jobs tesco news online shopping
story: Tesco Direct will cease trading in July putting 500 job at riskA spokesman said Tesco Direct will close on July 9, putting 500 colleagues at risk of redundancy.A statement issued by the company today confirmed the &ldquonon-food website will close the website in July - although its normal food website will remain ope.The statement blamed high costs and marketing for stunting the website&rsquos progress.The Tesco Direct centre in Milton Keynes will also be closed.Tesco Direct is set to close, putting 500 jobs at riskCharles Wilson, CEO of Tesco UK &amp ROI, said: We want to offer our customers the ability to buy groceries and non-food products in one place and that&rsquos why we are focusing our investment into one online platform.This decision has been a very difficult one to make, but it is an essential step towards establishing a more sustainable non-food offer and growing our business for the future.Non-food items will be moved over to the usual Tesco website with the statement saying this process has already begun.It said: &ldquoCustomers shopping on Tesco can already buy products such as toys, home and cookware.Tesco Direct is set to be closed with 500 jobs at riskThe news comes on the same day that Marks &amp Spencer announced that it is to swing the axe on over 100 stores, putting thousands of retail jobs at risk.Joanne McGuinness, national officer for the Usdaw union, said: This is devastating news for Tesco Direct staff.Usdaw officials and senior reps will now enter into consultation talks with the company where we will look closely at the business case for the proposed closure.Our priorities will be to support, advise and represent our members through this difficult period, and to get the best possible deal for them.

title: brexit news scotland independence referendum theresa may nicola sturgeon stop brexit
story: Brexit news: Theresa May faces a difficult decision over Scottish demands for the Brexit BillBy refusing Holyrood&rsquos demands on the EU Withdrawal Bill, the Prime Minister could inadvertently begin the break up of the United Kingdom, Akash Paun said.The Senior Fellow at the Institute for Government think-tank warned any attempt by Mrs May to block Scotland&rsquos request for a powerful veto over major changes post-Brexit could ultimately spell disaster for the future of the British Union.His warning comes after Holyrood last week rejected the Government&rsquos Brexit plans in a landslide vote, a move which could prove to be a major stumbling block in the orce with Brussels.Mr Paun said: &ldquoThe Prime Minister therefore faces a choice. Concede defeat on the Withdrawal Bill, at the expense of losing some control over post-Brexit regulatory arrangements.                British MEP tears into Nicola Sturgeon over fresh independence bid                Tory MP says Sturgeon will use ANYTHING to break Britain apart&ldquoOr hold course on Brexit, and prepare for a bigger battle over the future of the British Union.MSPs from the Scottish National Party (SNP), Labour, the Liberal Democrats and Scottish Greens voted by 93 to 30 to reject Mrs May&rsquos EU Withdrawal Bill.The vote was non-binding, but it did serve to highlight the strength of opposition to the Government&rsquos plans.As it stands, the EU Withdrawal Bill would require Westminster to consult with devolved parliaments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland before making changes to policies currently dealt with by Brussels, such as fishing quotas and farming subsidies.PANicola Sturgeon has again raised the possibility of a second Scottish independence voteBut First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has demanded Holyrood be given a veto on any changes it disagrees with.Mr Paun said the PM could chose to ignore Edinburgh&rsquos demands and just impose policy changes on Scotland.But he warned this course of action would be &ldquoused to bolster the case for a second independence referendum.The SNP leader has already warned her party would &ldquorestart a debate over independence in &ldquothe next couple of weeks.                David Coburn slams SNP for handing over Scotland to EUMs Sturgeon said once there was more clarity on Brexit, she would consider a second referendum.And Mr Paun said although Scots would likely vote against independence now, attitudes could quickly change if Westminster forced through major policy changes without the consent of SNPs.He said: &ldquoIt would be a gamble, no doubt. The polls do not indicate a pro-independence surge, but after the shock of 2016 only a fool would predict the outcome with confidence.The PM could risk boosting support for Scottish independence, Akash Paun said&ldquoWestminster could in principle refuse to allow another referendum, but emulating Madrid&rsquos handling of Catalonia would surely not be the right course of action.Scotland overwhelmingly backed Remain in the 2016 Brexit referendum, with 62 percent of voters supporting continued EU membership.In the 2014 independence referendum, 55.3 percent voted to remain part of the UK while 44.7 percent backed a split.

title: birthday party ideas cost parents thousands
story: NCScots parents organise a party for their children at an average cost of &pound270A survey conducted by the Bank of Scotland shows that nearly half of all Scots parents organise a party for their children at an average cost of &pound270.The How Scotland Lives research showed that providing entertainment for the guests is the most expensive apsect of organising a party, coming in on average at &pound90.As a result, almost half of parents plan their own party games for their children.Deciding just who to invite is another problem, with two per cent of respondents saying they invite their child&rsquos whole class. However, the average number attending each party is ten.                 EU plans to BAN plastic plates and balloons from children&rsquos parties                WATCH: Meghan LAUGHS as BEE swoops SHOCKED Prince Harry mid speechOne in four parties are reported to be event-based, taking place in venues such as bowling alleys or swimming pools.Almost three-quarters of parents choose to buy and hand out a gift bags at their children&rsquos parties, with the average total spend per celebration being &pound36.Yesterday, Ricky Diggins, director for Bank of Scotland, said: &ldquoIt&rsquos great to see how parties remain a firm favourite for kids celebrating their birthdays.&ldquoClearly, the various costs incurred in throwing a birthday party will put many parents under pressure to budget carefully.&ldquoIndeed our How Scotland Lives research shows that, while many are happy to make their own entertainment, very few will skip the traditional party food and drink.

title: daily express crusade minister for elderly pensioners uk government
story: STOCKThe  is calling for pensioners to have a dedicated ministerThe move has been prompted by a series of sickening attacks on the elderly, including the murder of pensioner Rose Coleman, 85, in Romford, east London, last week.About a million older people are victims of physical, financial, psychological and sexual abuse each year, but campaigners say criminal convictions are rare and sentences far too lenient.George McNamara, of the older people&rsquos charity Independent Age, said: &ldquoOlder people are often penalised when it comes to policy making by not having a champion within Government. This must change.&ldquoAs a country, we need to harness and give a greater value to the contribution that people make in their communities in later life, and that requires political leadership and commitment.                Elder abuse: &lsquoNational tragedy&rsquo as law fails our elderly yet again                Elderly abuse: We need CCTV in EVERY care home, says Attorney GeneralNCJane Ashcroft is chief executive of the not-for-profit elderly housing specialist Anchor&ldquoWe need a Minister for Older People that has real teeth and the clout in Government to influence across Whitehall, with all government policies and initiatives being assessed against the impact they have on older people.Because age is not a strand of hate crime under current legislation, prosecutors are unable to apply for tougher sentences for those who abuse the elderly.The situation has seen those guilty of sickening physical attacks and doorstep cons given &ldquoslap on the wrist community sentences instead of jail.Backers for our campaign say a Minister for the Elderly could lead the fight for a change in the law so crimes against vulnerable pensioners are recognised as aggravated offences, like crimes motivated by race, sexual orientation, disability or domestic abuse are.AGE UKCaroline Abrahams, charity director at Age UKThe Minister could also help halt the shocking number of cases of abuse and neglect suffered by pensioners in care homes across the UK.Caroline Abrahams, charity director at Age UK, said: &ldquoThere is a real need for a strong voice for older people in government, but at the moment there is no one minister, unit or strategy focused on this substantial and growing section of our population.&ldquoFor as long as this is the case the big issues for older people risk being overlooked by decisio-nmakers, so it&rsquos high time it changes.&ldquoThe fact that the  is campaigning for a Minister for Older People is great news. A named minister could help hold Government departments to account on issues that affect older people.Jane Ashcroft, chief executive of the not-for-profit elderly housing specialist Anchor, also backed our campaign.She said: &ldquoWe&rsquove been calling for a Minister for Older People for the past six years but never has the need been greater than now.&ldquoIn 2011, 137,000 people signed a petition for a Minister for Older People, including organisations working with older people, celebrities and more than 100 MPs.&ldquoWith the ever-deepening social care crisis, now is the time for the Government to act and ensure that the needs of our ageing population are addressed.Make money from your bank account and improve your finances with these easy money saving hacks.                    Getty1 of 10Savings - Regularly transferring a small amount into your savings account will soon add up and you'll hardly notice that it has gone&ldquoThe major areas of concern for older people &ndash housing, health and social care &ndash are currently spread across different departments. These can only be efficiently addressed by the appointment of a Minister for Older People, one with enough influence to unite these departments.&ldquoOlder people&rsquos issues cannot be addressed in isolation because they often impact more than one government department. For example, relaxing restrictions on building retirement properties will result in less demand on the NHS.&ldquoOnly through a dedicated minister can the Government send a clear message that it is serious about addressing the needs of today&rsquos and future generations of older people. We fully back the  calling for a Minister for Older People.In 2012, MPs unanimously urged the Government to consider creating a Minister for Older People.The decision was reached after a cross-party group of backbenchers, who said elderly members of society are often overlooked by politicians, launched a Commons debate on the subject. But there has been no responsibility handed to a cabinet minister.TIM CLARKEBaroness Altmann is a Campaigner for older peopleSo this is how 21st century Britain repays proud old folk, says&nbspBARONESS ALTMANN,&nbspCampaigner for older peopleI commend the  for its excellent campaign to highlight the need for a dedicated minister for older people and hopefully ensure they, to whom we owe a huge debt of gratitude, are treated with the dignity, care and respect they deserve.Latest research on digital discrimination is another shocking indictment of the way so many older people are treated in Britain today.The most worrying aspect is that it is Government itself which is discriminating against older people.People already in their late 70s or 80s, who had no opportunity to learn about technology, cannot be expected to master online transactions at this stage of their lives.Many may be disabled or live alone, which makes such age discrimination particularly heartless.These people built Britain into the success it is today, often served loyally in wartime, then worked hard to rebuild the country in the post-war years. They have sacrificed much for our country.We must not let them down. Housing and council tax benefits can be a lifeline for older people. It seems many are being denied this money just because they cannot cope with filling in online application forms. STOCKBaroness Altmann supports the  campaign for a Minister for the elderly Many will still be alive for another 20 or more years and must be allowed to claim their entitlements for many years into the future. Many elderly people have nobody to help them fill in online forms, or are too proud or embarrassed to ask for help.So they go without. This is unacceptable in 21st-century Britain. I call on the Government to establish a minister with special responsibility for older generations.For far too long the elderly have been considered a viable target to take money from in order to help younger generations.Most young people would not wish to see older citizens deprived of rights or left in poverty and we need a cross-Government approach to ensuring no generations are unfairly penalised. STOCKThose who cannot use online services usually lose out, says Baroness AltmannWhen I was pensions minister, it was proposed I should take on the role of minister for the ageing society, liaising across various departments. The idea was dropped by David Cameron, but I would love to see Theresa May establish this role.Digital discrimination extends well beyond being unable to claim benefits.Those who cannot use online services usually lose out in banking. They are denied the best rates on savings accounts &ndash and in insurance &ndash being unable to shop around for more competitive quotes.We must not let this go unchallenged and having a minister responsible for ensuring older citizens are not marginalised by the advances taking place in technology would be a positive way of ensuring government is aware of the needs of the older generations.

title: Brexit news Michael Gove blasts Philip Hammond for Brexit defeat House of Lords
story: GettyA source from the Treasury stated Mr Gove was 'clearly wrong' to blame Mr HammondThe Environment Secretary declared the Treasury&rsquos opposition to his plans for a new green watchdog resulted in the EU Withdrawal Bill blow.In a letter, Mr Gove wrote: &ldquoAs I explained at Cabinet on Tuesday, the short-sightedness of the Treasury has now led to an entirely predictable and avoidable defeat on the EU Withdrawal Bill and inflicted a damaging blow to the Government&rsquos environmental credentials.The MP for Surrey Heath insisted the Government will need to make &ldquosignificant concessions to overturn the amendment from the unelected Lords.He added it is critical that we now confront the reality of our position and emphasised ministers cannot afford to repeat the mistakes of recent weeks and have the Government's environmental credibility further undermined.                Rees-Mogg fears fine words but NO BREXIT ACTION leading UK back to EU                'Perhaps you are horrified?' Farage declares Facebook made Brexit In his letter to Cabinet colleagues last week, seen by The , Mr Gove warned the Government would face a defeat on the Withdrawal Bill because of the reality of the parliamentary arithmetic.He stated: &ldquoDefra argued that if we were to deliver the Government&rsquos promises our proposals must at the very least replicate the status quo - specifically the enforcement powers of the European Commission and maintenance of the principles in legislation.&ldquoMore than that, we argued that the reality of the parliamentary arithmetic meant we would be defeated if we chose to publish a weak consultation.&ldquoDefra&rsquos arguments were not accepted as a result of Treasury opposition.The day after his warning, the House of Lords inflicted the Government with a defeat on EU environment protection by a majority of 294 to 244.The latest decision from the unelected peers took the total tally of Brexit defeats to 15 for the Government&rsquos EU Withdrawal Bill.Mr Gove has argued a new post-Brexit environment watchdog with a capability to fine the Government and authorities if they do not cut pollution and increase recycling are vital for a &ldquogreen Brexit.However the Chancellor has countered the Environment Secretary by claiming greater powers for the watchdog could damage the UK&rsquos economy by creating more red tape after it frees itself from the clutches of Brussels.GettyMr Gove warned the Government would face a defeat on the Withdrawal BillGettyMr Hammond has claimed greater powers for the watchdog could damage the UK&rsquos economyA source from the Treasury stated Mr Gove was &ldquoclearly wrong to blame Mr Hammond for the latest Brexit defeat.They said: It is clearly wrong to blame the Treasury for this.&ldquoPhilip has worked closely with Michael to support the Government's environmental agenda, including on plans for a plastic waste tax.Plans published by the Government surrounding a new watchdog were labelled &ldquotoothless by environment groups earlier this month.

title: house of lords Theresa May Jeremy Corbyn electoral reform uk politics
story: It is estimated to add &pound1,079,000 to the annual &pound68million bill for running the LordsThe PM and the Labour leader faced criticism after appointing a list of 13 new members to the House of Lords on the eve of the Royal Wedding.It is estimated to add &pound1,079,000 to the annual &pound68million bill for running the Lords, according to an analysis by the Electoral Reform Society (ERS).Darren Hughes of the ERS, which is campaigning to reform the Lords, said the appointment was &ldquoan insult to voters.He added: &ldquoThis has now gone beyond a joke.                Theresa May swells Lords with Tory peers who SUPPORT Brexit plan                Michael Gove BLASTS &lsquoshort-sighted&rsquo Philip Hammond for Brexit DEFEAT&ldquoTime and time again the Government talks about reducing the cost of politics.&ldquoYet at the same time they&rsquore packing the Upper House with former MPs and retired party hacks.&ldquoIf Mrs May was serious about reducing the cost of politics, she would halt these appointments rather than providing yet more fuel for public concern about cronyism.&ldquoIt is an insult to voters.The House of Lords is already the largest parliamentary chamber in any democracy with 780 members.Darren Hughes of the ERS said the appointment was 'an insult to voters'It is second only to the National People&rsquos Congress in communist China.Peers can claim travel expenses on top of a &pound305-a-day living allowance just for turning up.Mrs May appointed her close friend Catherine Meyer and seven former Conservative MPs.No 10 claims the PM will now show &ldquorestraint in appointing new peers.It added it reserves the right to make appointments in order to &ldquorefresh the Lords.But critics pointed out one of her new Peers, Sir Alan Haselhurst, will turn 81 next month.The Labour leader once pledged to never appoint any PeersAnother Tory Peer includes Andrew Tyrie who resigned the Party whip and said he would sit as an independent.The decision is thought to be linked to his role as head of the Competition and Markets Authority.The Labour leader once pledged to never appoint any Peers.But now he has appointed two personal friends, veteran left-wing activists Martha Osamor and Paulin Bryan.Ms Osamor was one barred from standing for Labour in the 1980s because of her hard-left views.She is also the mother of Labour&rsquos Shadow International Development Secretary Kate Osamor.Mr Corbyn also handed a peerage to former union official and Labour Party General Secretary Iain McNicol.

title: brexit news BBC newsnight Caroline Flint Tony Blair second referendum customs union
story: BBCCaroline Flint stated the UK should not remain in the customs union or single market post-BrexitSpeaking to&nbspKirsty Wark on BBC Newsnight, Ms Flint slammed Remoaner MPs for denying the will of the British people by seeking to remain in the customs union and single market which would effectively see the UK remain in the EU.She said: &ldquoI think Tony Blair is wrong on this, the people do not want a second referendum.&ldquoI think we are going to have to get the best deal we can and also think about the sort of policies we should have been thinking about for many years to increase skills and increase our productivity.&ldquoIf we are leaving the European Union, then we cannot be in the single market nor in the customs union as it currently stands.                Jacob Rees-Mogg BLASTS Theresa May for &lsquopreparing for Brexit FAILURE'                Boris Johnson REFUSES to back demands for Brexit bank holiday BBCMs Flint accused Remainer MPs of disrespecting the result of the referendum&ldquoYou cannot have a situation where we are frankly disrespectful to the vote of the referendum, which is to say that we want everything we&rsquove got now, which means we are not leaving.She lambasted Remoaner Labour MPs, stating: &ldquoPeople should be honest about that - they don&rsquot want us to leave and that&rsquos why they are saying we should be in the single market and customs union.The Labour MP also rejected suggestions that opinions are changing in regards to Brexit.She said: &ldquoI don&rsquot think there is much evidence opinions are changing.&ldquoIn the campaign a majority voted leave, but 40 per cent of Remain voters also wanted to change freedom of movement.&ldquoSo just on the issue of freedom of movement, there is a far bigger majority for that to change than just the inout vote.In outlining her own vision for the ongoing Brexit negotiations, she added: &ldquoThe truth is these negotiations are going to have to come up with a deal which is bespoke for the UK.&ldquoIf we can negotiate a customs relationship then that is something to think about - because that is part of what works with other countries too.Citing the car industry in particular, she said: &ldquoIf you think of the car industry that brokers parts of cars that travel across Europe - that might be an area where we can come to an arrangement on.Theresa May sought to unite EU leaders in condemnation of Moscow over the poisoning of a former Russian spy, but she faces resistance from states keen to protect their Kremlin ties                    REUTERS1 of 17Jean-Claude Juncker and Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May&ldquoThe truth is there are companies in other parts of the EU which are lobbying in their countries to say, &lsquolook the UK is important to us, you&rsquove got to get a deal&rsquo.However Ms Flint is in opposition to the leadership of the Labour party, which backs a continued membership of the customs union, but not the European Economic Area.Commenting on Labour&rsquos official position, BBC Newsnight political editor Nicholas Watt said: &ldquoThe leadership supports a customs union because they believe that gives the ability for a tariff-free movement of goods, but it would also allow the UK to have a say in trade deals that the EU was to sign around the world.&ldquoThe leadership is opposed the European Economic Area membership, as they say this that would lead to free movement.&ldquoIt would mean the UK would be subject to the rules of the single market, so the UK would be a rule taker not a rule maker.

title: UK weather forecast Met Office May bank holiday 2018
story: UK weather this weekend: What is the Met Office weather forecast for May Bank Holiday 2018?A heatwave is set to hit the UK this week, with temperatures soaring into the high 20s over the May Bank Holiday, according to the Met Office.&nbspBut thunderstorms will batter the country on Bank Holiday Monday, as rising temperatures from France cover Britain.The weekend is set to kick off 10 straight days of hot weather, giving Britons a taste of the summer.&nbspHigh pressure in the air will subside by mid-week, reducing the risk of showers across the country.                UK hot weather forecast: Chart shows Britain set for Bank Holiday HEAT                Bank holiday 2018: What is the UK weather forecast this weekend Thunderstorms are expected to hit the UK on MondayIn&nbspLondon,&nbsptemperatures could reach 29C with highs of 20C in the north.&nbspNicky Maxey from the Met Office said: On Saturday, temperatures in the South East and London could rise to 28C or even 29C.Other&nbspparts of the UK, such as Bristol and Southampton, could also see temperatures of 27C or 28C.The North East, including Newcastle, could also see temperatures of around 20C this bank holiday weekend.Brits are looking forward to a sunny Bank Holiday MondayLadbrokes have slashed odds to 21 for this weekend becoming one of the hottest Spring Bank Holidays on record.&nbspSoaring temperatures in 2018 could mean the summer months will be the hottest ever, and Ladbrokes say this could be the hottest Spring Bank Holiday Monday ever.&nbspJessica Bridge of Ladbrokes said: The heatwave may be slightly interrupted by the storms, but that hasn't deterred optimistic punters from wagering the Spring Bank Holiday will be the hottest ever.The mercury will remain above average across most of the UK this week, except in Scotland, according to the Weather Channel.A Weather Channel spokesman said: &ldquoWeak pressure gradients under higher pressure will keep conditions mostly sunny with maximum temperatures between 3C and 5C above normal and higher in places.&ldquoThe exception being over Ireland and north Scotland where the proximity of a cold front will maintain mostly cloudy weather with rain, or showers, moderate south-westerly winds.&ldquoIt will be less warm with nearer to normal temperatures.

title: UK weather Met Office forecast Britain to melt over bank holiday weekend 30C temperatures
story: Getty &bull WX ChartsBoiling conditions could defy expectations and push the UK towards another recordThe Met Office has insisted parts of the south-east of England could double average temperatures for the time of year.A spokesman said: &ldquoThe average temperature for this time of year is 15C.&ldquoCurrently, temperatures are averaging 20C and are only going to get warmer this weekend.Although the weather body warned stated temperatures may not reach record highs of 32.8 that were seen in 1944, the boiling conditions could defy expectations and push the UK towards another record.                Bank Holiday weekend weather: Will there be a heatwave? Latest UK w...                How to get to sleep in hot weather: Do the with your pillowsThe spokesman went on: &ldquoThe maximum temperature ever for the end of May bank holiday is 32.8C, which came in Horsham, Sussex, on 29 May 1944.With temperatures continuing to skyrocket, bookmaker Coral has cut its odds on 30C or higher being hit over the bank holiday.The company&rsquos spokesman, Harry Aitkenhead, commented: &ldquoThere may be some showers around over the next few days but the Bank Holiday weekend looks set to be a sweltering one and some parts of the country will be in with a chance of reaching as high as 30 degrees.&ldquoIt might be more punters betting with their hearts over their heads but this prolonged period of warm weather is prompting another rush of bets on 2018 being a record breakingly hot one.It is the warmest May bank holiday since records began.                    EPA1 of 18Eveyln, 4, runs down the beach with a bucket and spade as she enjoys the hot Bank Holiday weather in MargateMeanwhile, meteorologist Alex Deakin insisted Wednesday will start off &ldquogrey and murky before the sun continues a trend of sweltering heat.He said: &ldquoInto Wednesday we are going to stark quite grey and murky across much of the Midlands, eastern England and parts of eastern Scotland.&ldquoBut quite quickly once the sun gets up the mist and low cloud will tend to melt away, certainly melt away inland but close to some coasts it may just stay murky for much of the day.&ldquoMist and low cloud will have a big impact on temperatures because in the sunshine in the west we will see values into the low twenties easily once more.&ldquoIt will be a much warmer and sunnier day across much of Scotland.However, Mr Deakin warned temperatures could struggle to hit double digits along some eastern coasts.He noted: &ldquoBut on the east coast it will be significantly cooler and especially if it stays quite misty and murky - temperatures are really going to struggle in some places, barely getting into the teens in some places they may struggle to get into double digits.&ldquoBut it does make a big difference, if you are on the coast or just a bit inland in Norwich for example in the sunshine we could easily get into the high teens.&ldquoThere is the threat the warmth may spark one or two late showers across the south, they will be pretty isolated but they could also be pretty intense.The Met Office forecaster said an increased threat of showers will emerge on Wednesday evening and will continue to plague parts of the nation through Thursday.GettyBritain is set to melt over the bank holiday weekend as temperatures reach roasting highs of 30CHowever, much of the country will continue to bask in gorgeous climates.Mr Deakin went on: &ldquoAs we go through Wednesday evening we will start to see a greater risk of showers coming up from the near continent, these will be quite heavy again and may well turn into thunderstorms and they will be drifting across parts of the south on Thursday.&ldquoAgain on Thursday eastern coasts may stay a bit misty and murky.Met OfficeAlex Deakin insisted Wednesday will start off 'grey and murky' before sweltering heat takes over&ldquoFor the most part of Thursday it is another sunny and warm day but the risk of downpours will increase through the day.&ldquoIt is too early to say exactly where the showers will be hit but they could be quite heavy once more and thundery too.&ldquoAs for the outlook well it is more of the same really, there will be plenty of hazy sunshine and if anything it is going to turn warmer towards the end of the week and there is the continued threat of heavy thundery showers across parts of the south.

title: mh370 malaysia airlines pilot australia search latest news
story: MH370, which had 239 people on board, vanished on March 8, 2014 off the coast of Western Australia during a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, having apparently veered wildly off course. The jet's whereabouts have remained a mystery ever since.One theory claims the pilot conducted a series of manouveres to ditch the plane - but expertstoday argued it would have been impossible for him to remain conscious during the emergency landing.Investigators were originally exploring the possibility that Captain Zaharie Amad Shah carried out a series of manoeuvres to evade detection to ensure the flight &ldquodisappeared in a remote location, as seen on Australian TV programme 60 Minutes.The programme and its aviation experts alleged that Zaharie de-pressurised the plane to incapacitate passengers and other crew through oxygen deficiency, while keeping his own emergency air supply open, before re-pressurising the plane for the rest of the journey.NCCaptain Zaharie Amad Shah and the doomed MH370 flightFlight MH370: Pilot accuses Australian government of being complicitBut contradicting the theory, the current head of the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) Peter Foley - who has been in the position since 2014 - suggested to the Australian Senate the pilot was unconscious when the plane crashed into the Indian ocean, resulting in a steep e, along with other theories.Mr Foley told the Senate the theory the pilot deliberately crashed the plane was plausible but stressed he would have been knocked out by sudden pressure change way before switching on his own emergency supply.Mr Foley said: &ldquoMost of the people out there are speculating about a long period of de-pressurisation after the transponder went off. They say this may have been as long as an hour.&ldquoWhat they fail to understand is that while you don an oxygen mask and prevent the worst of the hypoxia situation, you are flying an aircraft at 40,000 feet.Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 Remembered. Flight MH370 disappeared on March 8, 2014 from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. After one year and an exhaustive search, investigators still have no clue as to the whereabouts of the missing airline                    AFPGetty Images1 of 19A family member of a passenger missing on Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 cries during a protest near the Malaysian embassy in Beijing on March 8, 2015You are taking an aircraft from sea level to Mt Kosciuszko in 20 minutes, then you are taking it, over the course of a couple of minutes, to the height of Mt Everest plus 1,000 feet. You&rsquoll get decompression sickness too.Pointing to an emergency landing of a cargo aircraft in 1994, documented by the US National Transportation Safety Board, he told the Senate: &ldquoDuring the climb out, the flight crew was unable to pressurise the aircraft, and the captain elected to proceed with the flight.The crew donned their oxygen masks and shortly thereafter the captain became incapacitated from decompression sickness. The first officer took command and they landed the plane.&ldquoThe pilot in this particular aircraft was 51 and overweight. The pilot in command of MH370 was 53 and overweight. I&rsquom not saying that happened and I hate to speculate, but that is one plausible scenario.In May Martin Dolan, former ATSB head, who led the two-year search for the missing plane, said: &ldquoThis was planned, this was deliberate, and it was done over an extended period of time.John Dawson, a lawyer who represented nine families from MH370 and MH17, backed up the claims saying the evidence suggested one of the aircrew was responsible.He said: &ldquoIn MH370, you have the pilot flying between Malaysia and Beijing who turns back the aircraft. The evidence is so heavily weighted to involvement by one of the aircrew taking this aircraft down.&ldquoThat aircraft has probably de-pressurised, the people died of asphyxiation, it was premeditated murder.It was highly planned. The bodies have never been found.

title: Italy latest Matteo Salvini Lega France La Meire
story: Lega leader Matteo Salvini said France should stay out of Italy's internal affairsLego, which is ruling alongside Five Star Movement, has vowed to put Italy first with a controversial governing accord that would cut taxes and boost welfare spending.Mr Salvini said on Twitter: &ldquoA French minister has &lsquowarned&rsquo the future government: change nothing or you will have problems. Another unacceptable invasion of territory. I did not call for votes and for people&rsquos confidence to continue going down the road of poverty, instability and immigration: Italians first!&ldquoThe French should look after France and stop poking their nose into other people&rsquos affairs, he told a press conference later that day.Mr Le Maire warned Mr Salvini and the head of the populist Five Star, Luigi di Maio &ndash the two driving forces behind Italy&rsquos new coalition government &ndash against breaking the bloc&rsquos fiscal rules, before urging them to maintain eurozone stability. Italy is currently the eurozone&rsquos third largest economy.                EU DIVIDED: Salvini tells Weber to 'focus on Germany' after dig at ...The government &ldquocontract between the two hardline parties that won the most parliamentary seats in the March 4 election calls for billions of euros in tax cuts, additional spending on welfare for the poor and a roll-back on pension reforms &ndash proposals which seem incompatible with EU rules on fiscal discipline.Mr Le Maire said in a joint interview with Europe 1 radio, Les Echos newspaper and the CNews television channel: &ldquoIf the new government takes the risk of not respecting its commitments on debt and the deficit, but also the clean-up of banks, the financial stability of the eurozone will be threatened.&ldquoEveryone in Italy must understand that Italy&rsquos future is in Europe and nowhere else, and that for that future to be in Europe, there are rules that must be respected&hellip no matter who is in power.&ldquoI respect the sovereign decision of the Italian people, but there are commitments which go beyond all of us.French minister Bruno Le Maire called on Italy's government to remain committed to EU fiscal policy Brussels predicts that Italian public debt will remain 130 per cent above its GDP in 2018, more than double the 60 per cent ceiling.Mr Le Maire warned: &ldquoWe will see what decisions are taken by Italian officials. I cannot stress enough how important it is to keep these commitments in the long-term to guarantee our common stability.While the government pact contains no reference to a possible exit from the euro, it underlines the parties&rsquo intention to review &ldquowith European partners the economic government framework of the EU, including the euro.The two parties also said that they wanted a monetary union that is &ldquoappropriate for the current geopolitical and economic imbalances and consistent with the objectives of the economic union.

title: north korea news nuclear site destruction kim jong un
story: North Korea&rsquos destruction of its nuclear test site has been likened to destroying evidenceNorth Korea will be dismantling its Punggye-ri nuclear site this week after Kim Jong-un announced the nation would take steps towards denuclearisation.However nuclear scientists and North Korea experts fear vital evidence of Kim Jong-un&rsquos nuclear ambitions will be destroyed.North Korea has invited a handful of media representatives to witness the dismantling of the Punggye-ri site but not technical experts despite calls from the US for a permanent and irreversible closure that can be inspected and fully accounted for.Bruce Bechtol, an expert on North Korea, has likened the destruction of the nuclear test site to trampling on a murder scene.Mr Bechtol, a professor of political science at Angelo State University, said: &ldquoIt's kind of like a murder scene where they let people like you and me trample around in it, it's the same concept.                World War 3: USA WILL go to war with North Korea if talks fall through                North Korea summit in CRISIS - Trump says Kim meeting might NOT happen&ldquoThe North Koreans have conducted all these tests here, every single weapons test, so if they let experts in to look at these tunnels before they let anyone else in that would be potentially for us an intelligence boon.Sceptics also warn Pyongyang has a history of going back on its word and could quickly rebuild the nuclear site if diplomatic talks deteriorateIn 2008 the regime blew up a cooling tower of its atomic reactor at Yongbyon, the facility that produced the plutonium for North Korea&rsquos first successful nuclear test.The ceremony was held with much fanfare, complete with international journalists, and was heralded as a mark of Pyongyang&acutes commitment to denuclearisation talks.However, when talks collapsed the Yongbyon cooling tower was quickly rebuilt and the reactor restarted.North Korea will be dismantling its Punggye-ri nuclear site this weeKim Hyun-wook, an expert at the Korea National Diplomatic Academy, said: &ldquoFrankly a nuclear test site can be easily reassembled.&ldquoBut still, by dismantling it, North Korea is showing its willingness to not conduct nuclear tests at least for a while and signalling it has sufficient number of nuclear weapons.Meanwhile Yang Moo-jin, from the University of North Korean Studies, suggest more significance needed to place on Pyongyang willingness to not use the site's destruction as a &ldquobargaining chip before summit between Kim and Donald Trump in Singapore on June 12.He added: &ldquoThis move testifies sincerity in the North's commitment to defusing tension through negotiations.About two dozen journalists from Western and Chinese news organisations arrived in North Korea on Tuesday to witness the closure of its nuclear test site, an indication that the shutdown will go ahead despite renewed diplomatic uncertainty.North Korea's offer to scrap the test site was seen as a key concession in months of easing tension between Pyongyang and its long-time bitter rivals, South Korea and the US.Photographer Eric Lafforgue ventured to North Korea six times. Thanks to digital memory cards, he was able to save photos that was forbidden to take inside the segregated state                     Eric LafforgueExclusivepix Medi1 of 69Taking pictures in the DMZ is easy, but if you come too close to the soldiers, they stop youHowever, the improving diplomatic environment has hit a rocky patch, with North Korea threatening last week to pull out of a planned June 12 summit in Singapore between leader Kim Jong-un and Donald Trump.Journalists from the Associated Press, CNN, CBS, Russia Today and Chinese state media outlets were among those seen checking in at Beijing Capital International Airport to catch the Air Koryo flight to North Korea.Chinese state broadcaster CCTV said the group had arrived at the airport in the east coast city of Wonsan.Numerous other news organisations, including Reuters, had also sought to cover the shutdown of the North's nuclear test site but were denied invitations.South Korea expressed regret that its journalists had not been included after earlier being invited.South Korea's Unification Ministry said in a statement: &ldquoNonetheless, the government pays due attention to the fact that the North's pledge to dismantle the Punggyeri nuclear test site, an initial measure for denuclearisation, is proceeding as planned, and expects that such action to lead to the successful hosting of the North Korea-US summit.

title: Russia set to exploit Emmanuel Macron as France negotiates with Vladimir Putin
story: GettyMr Macron will head to St Petersburg on Thursday as part of a two day visit to RussiaThe director of the Russia centre at the Paris-based Institute for International Relations, Tatiana Kastoueva-Jean, insisted Donald Trump&rsquos decision to remove the US from the Iran nuclear deal has weakened Mr Macron&rsquos position and will be taken advantage of by Russia.He said: &ldquoThe weakness of the transatlantic relationship does not give Macron sufficiently strong positions to counter Putin.&ldquoPutin knows that there are differences in the Western camp and as soon as someone shows weakness he exploits it.Jalel Harchaoui, a geopolitics researcher at Paris 8 University, insisted the French leader&rsquos efforts with Putin have been one-sided as he desperately attempts to gain concessions from the superstate.                Russia to launch new fleet of ROBOT WAR MACHINES in fight against ISISHe said: &ldquoBeyond France&rsquos prestige and commercial opportunities, an effective French diplomacy must ask what levers it can use vis-&agrave-vis recalcitrant actors.&ldquoIt seems this basic question is no longer being asked in Paris.&ldquoWhen you conduct foreign policy without a carrot or a stick, that&rsquos what you get.Mr Macron will head to St Petersburg on Thursday as part of a two day visit to Russia.It is understood the French leader will not confront Putin on matters publicly and will instead resort to private meetings to discuss international matters.The visit from Mr Macron comes during a period of heavy sanctions on Moscow from the European Union.The leader will attempt to salvage the Iran nuclear deal following the US&rsquos withdrawal despite differing interests between Russia, China, the UK and Berlin.Vladimir Putin has so far refused to budge on matters concerning Russia's position in Syria, where Moscow backs the Bashar al-Assad government.GettyVladimir Putin has so far refused to budge on matters concerning SyriaThe superstate has also excluded discussions on ever restoring the Crimea region following its annexation in 2014.Despite Russia&rsquos use of a military grade nerve agent in Salisbury on Sergei Skripal and his daughter in March, Mr Macron has refused to rule out ostracising Putin&rsquos superstate.A senior French diplomat insisted &ldquoa lot needs to be done during the visit as part of the nation&rsquos desperate attempt to change the position of Russia.GettyMr Macron will be the guest of honour to an economic forum taking place on FridayThey noted: &ldquoA lot needs to be done to convince the Russians because it has interests in the Middle East, especially Syria, and its stance towards the West is aggressive.Mr Macron will be the guest of honour to an economic forum taking place on Friday that will include other attendees such as those from French oil company Total.The leader will use the occasion to try and improve trade with Russia and boost French exports.

title: President Emmanuel Macron braced new strikes France rail unions SNCF
story: GettyFrance rail unions will announce the results of a staff ballot to prevent the government's reforms  The unions called the vote &lsquoa referendum&rsquo and announced it a few days after Air France employees forced the resignation of Air France KLM&rsquos chief executive.The state-appointed boss of the SNCF railways, Guillaume Pepy, said the vote is nothing more than a petition deprived of any legal value.However, the rail unions hope the vote will inject fresh energy into the rolling strikes.The rail workers strikes started at the beginning of April and have caused disruption to the country&rsquos 4.5 million train users since then.                Macron BACKLASH: Fiery scenes as 15,000 protest in Paris                 Vladimir Putin set to &lsquoEXPLOIT weak&rsquo Macron in negotiations this weekThe intense industrial action has been an attempt to prevent the government's reform of the SNCF rail operator which will gradually end the SNCF&rsquos monopoly of passenger train services in France.This includes job-for-life contracts, seven-hour days and generous pensions that were customary for most of the 150,000 people who work at the railways.The government also wants to turn SNCF into a joint-stock company whose shares would be held by the state - a move unions see as a first step towards privatisation.The unions claims over the government plans to privatise the country's railways have been denied by ministers as well as SNCF chiefs.A nationwide day protest by French public sector employees and public servants against the overhauls proposed by French President Macron.                     EPA1 of 15A papier-mache sculpture of French President Emmanuel Macron is set on fireMr Pepi said the railworkers' strikes could cost the SNCF &euro350-400million.So far, there has been no sign of backing up from President Emmanuel Macron who has already stared down the unions over labour law reforms.Reconsidering the plans on the SNCF would question the President&rsquos ability to deliver reforms which he claimed are vital to modernise France.The proposed legislation has already been approved by the lower house of parliament, where Macron&rsquos party dominates, but the upper chamber is expected to vote on it in the first week of June.On Friday, Prime Minister Edouard Philippe is set to meet with the unions and respond to proposed amendments to the draft bill.GettyThe strikes have caused disruption to the country&rsquos 4.5 million train users since April.GettyPresident Macron claimed the planned reforms are vital to modernise France. Citizens &mdash at least according to polls &mdash seem to be supportive of the government&rsquos effort to pass long-promised reforms, as many users claim the railways have suffered from debt-funded investment in the much-admired high-speed train network TGV.As part of the of the planned reforms to SNCF the French government plans to absorb about 35 billion euros.

title: national living wage uk 2018 increase minimum wage 16 18 25
story: But the amount is still below the Real Living Wage, a voluntary scheme to which thousands of employers including retailers, local authorities and charities have got involved.The National Living Wage is the amount of money all employees aged over 25 are legally entitled to.It used to be known as the National Minimum Wage, but it was re-branded in 2016.The National Living Wage increased from £7.50 to £7.83 for those aged 25 and over.The 33 pence-an-hour rise was introduced on Sunday April 1, 2018.The compulsory National Living Wage was introduced in 2016.The first National Minimum Wage was set in 1998 by the Labour government.Mr Hammond is aiming to get the wage to £9 by 2020.The National Minimum Wage is the amount which workers aged under 25, but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.However, the amount differs depending on age and whether the worker is on an apprenticeship scheme.Workers aged 21-24 were paid £7.05 - and it went up to £7.38 from April 1, 2018.The wage increased from £5.60 to £5.90 for 18 to 20-year-olds, and from £4.05 to £4.20 for under 18s.However, apprentices were only entitled to £3.50 if they are under-19 - this increased to £3.70 from April 1, 2018.In April 2018, the minimum wage for 25-year-olds rose from £7.50 to £7.83 an hour.The national limits are legally binding.Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualify for either rate.There is no difference in pay for those that live in London compared to elsewhere.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October 1, 2013 are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.This is a voluntary scheme aiming to recognise the actual cost of living, to which 3,000 employers have signed up.Under it, the lowest rate of pay is calculated according to the cost of living in the UK based on the changing cost of a basket of groceries.The amount is set by the charity Living Wage Foundation, and accredited employers include local authorities, NHS trusts, banks, retailers, charities and construction companies.The foundations calculations put the real Living Wage at £8.75 an hour - and £10.20 in London.These rates also apply to over-18s in recognition that young people face the same living costs as everyone else.And while companies are not legally entitled to pay more than the National Living and Minimum Wages, those which have signed up to the real Living Wage scheme have pledged to pay all workers those rates.The rate is calculated every November, and accredited employers are committed to any increases.While theres no legal obligation for your employer to pay you more than the National Living Wage (£7.50 from April 1, 2017), if your company is accredited by the Living Wage Foundation you should be receiving more than that.The foundations head of partnerships Graham Griffiths said anyone concerned can use their online whistleblowing service, and any employer not adhering to the Real Living Wage faced losing its accreditation.Graham said one area where it was challenging to pay the living wage were retail and hospitality but pointed to Ikea, Aldi and Lidl, which have agreed to pay the same rate.The scheme was launched in 2001 by parents in East London, and the foundation was set up in 2011.In 2005 following a growing interest from employers, the Greater London Authority established the Living Wage Unit to calculate what the lowest pay should ideally be.In 2008 Trust for London selected the scheme as a special initiative and made a grant of more than £1million to campaign for it and set up an accreditation scheme for employers.In April 2016 it became the inspiration for the governments higher minimum wage rate, which it rebranded the National Living Wage.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: norman scott jeremy thorpe gay relationship assassination trial
story: Here is everything you need to know about the male model who claimed the leader of a political party tried to kill him.Scott was the central figure in what was the trial of the century.For Liberal Party leader Thorpe went on trial for conspiracy to murder him after an apparently botched attempt on October 23, 1975.He is still alive and lives in Dartmoor. The two had been lovers after meeting in 1960 when being gay was banned.Scott, who worked as a model, was said to have had a full blown affair with the politician and even had liaisons in Thorpe’s Commons room.But after they parted, Thorpe was said to have viewed Scott as a dangerous blackmailer intent on revenge - something that could have wrecked his political ambitions.For while homosexuality was legalised in 1967 it was still taboo for people in the public eye.Scott had been lured on to Exmoor by a hitman, who was allegedly a part-time pilot called Andrew Newton who had been hired as part of the plot.He shot the model’s dog before turning the gun on Scott – but it jammed. Effing and jeffing, he sped off.After managing to hail down an approaching car, Scott blurted “Jeremy Thorpe” to the driver.A police investigation lead to a trial in the Old Bailey with the Liberal leader accused of conspiracy to murder along with three other men. But the jury did not feel convinced that Thorpe, a man of hitherto unblemished reputation and a national figure with a very distinguished public record could be capable of the crime. And he was acquitted along with the others.But Scott maintains Thorpe wanted him dead and said he only felt safe when the politician died in 2014.His younger self has been played by actor Ben Wishaw in the new BBC drama starring Hugh Grant called Very English Scandal.

title: labour has lost the working class vote now theresa may can grab their support if she lowers the sky high cost of living new book says
story: Labour has lost the support of the traditional workers and as a result, a huge wad of votes is now up for grabs in British politics, author Claire Ainsley argues.She suggests new policies such as an extra bank holiday, a crackdown on soaring shop prices and a massive housebuilding programme.Latest polling for YouGov shows that the Tories have overtaken Labour in lower classes of voters in the latest pattern of a worrying trend for the reds.Britain’s workers have flocked away to other parties, and last year Theresa May picked up a record number of them.Her policies squarely aimed at the just about managing sector of society paid off, as the JAMS proved they were not just set to vote for Labour.But without appealing to the new working class, no party can win an overall majority, Ainsley - executive of social policy research charity The Joseph Rowntree Foundation - says in The New Working Class.Mainstream politicians have focused too much on the middle class, swing voters, and not taken enough time to look at the changing nature of Britain’s army of workers.Radical changes to Britains economy and society means that the world of work is dramatically different than it was 40 years ago, and Labour voters have floated away.Tony Blair often said that Labour had been too slow to respond to this change, adding: “Society had changed and we did not change sufficiently with it.”Instead, they turned to the middle classes and tried to reach out to swing voters, in particularly aspirational workers who now might own their own home.But by 2005, the working class support for Labour had tailed off, and they had begun to not vote for anyone at all.The book says: “New Labour was right to suppose that Labour could now build a parliamentary majority based on the traditional working class alone, but they were wrong to assume those voters would have nowhere else to go.Today many of the new working class now earn less than the average annual income of £27,000.They are more likely to be female, and younger than the traditional working class image.The book argues that to win the hearts and minds of the new working class, political parties needed to appeal to their values of family, fairness, hard work and decency.Some of the suggested new policies include:She says that those working in the service sector, retail and hospitality all make up today’s working class - and it could reach around half of the population.About 14 per cent of the population used to be considered working class, but that’s all changed.“There is a working class, it’s new, and no political party is speaking for it,” she added.“There are millions of people today on low and middle incomes, and politicians need to wake up and start paying attention to them.“There’s a prize on offer for the parties who understand this.”People on low and middle incomes are less likely to associate with Labour now than they used to, she said.“Working class support for Labour has declined, it’s started to rise a bit for the Tories, and has definitely increased among the SNP.”Ukip also hoovered up a certain amount of the working class votes, but that has collapsed since the vote to leave the European Union in 2016 and the party struggles to find a new purpose.Ms Ainsley said the message for politicians was simple - tell voters what you are going to do, and then show them when you’ve done it.The New Working Class: how to win hearts, minds and votes, was written by Claire Ainsley, executive director of the Joseph Rowntree FoundationOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
